item.title: Report I-2022120107
item.description:
Report I-2022120107

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-12
  • City: BORGER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PANHANDLE NORTHERN RAILROAD LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Monday, September 12, 2022, at approximately 1508 CDT, PNR102 was in the process of building customer line-ups in the Borger yard when the PNR 102 Cndr smelt a foul odor coming from car CPCX 115068 located in Borger yard track LGT04. Simultaneously, PNR GM entered the Borger yard and contacted PNR 102. At this time, PNR102 Cndr reported the foul odor. PNR GM then notified CP Chem to investigate. Upon CP Chem ' s arrival to the Borger yard, it was determined that the odor and frost ball was caused by a loose vapor valve. CP Chem & Borger FD secured the site, adjusted the loose vapor valve, cleaned the frost ball, re-tested the vapor valve, and reported all clear. At 1824, the site was deemed safe, evacuation was lifted and rail operations could resume

  • Description: At 1228 EST, ERTS was contacted by XPO Logistics (LEP) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to unknown reasons, approximately 5 gallons of Blue Whale Muriatic Acid (Hazardous - UN1789) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor at dock door #43. ERTS dispatched GrayMar to conduct cleanup operations. At 1500 ET GrayMar personnel arrived onsite and reports that almost all of the boxes are wet from leaking caps on the one gallon poly jugs. The entire pallet of boxed jugs was broken down and containerized. Two 55 gallon and two 20 gallon poly drums were generated containing the jugs only. One 55 gallon poly drum containing the impacted cardboard, debris, and absorbent pads was also generated. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SNEU 144882 was discovered leaking clear liquid from a vapor line cap at the end of the tank. The Tank Closure on top of the tank was closed. Upon inspection it was found that a line valve was slightly open and product was present in the line. The vapor line cap gasket was cracked and leaking. The gasket was replaced, the valve closed and the liquid drained out of the line.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: XPO Terminal LDA contacted ERTS to make a notification of a one-gallon spill of regulated UN1789 "Blue Whale Muriatic Acid PH Reducer" the caller stated that at least 10-cases of 2 gallon poly jugs were impacted. ERTS dispatched LSHR to conduct cleanup. At 2350 ET, LSHR personnel arrived onsite and observed a release of approximately 1 gallon of Blue Whale Muriatic Acid PH Reducer UN1789. The release impacted the shipping packaging and the pallet on the trailer floor. Lone Star Environmental recovered the released with absorbents. One 55-gallon poly, and one 95-gallon poly drums were generated of waste. The waste was left on site for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Terminal LDA contacted ERTS to request cleaning assistance with a 55-gallon poly drum spill of regulated UN1197 "Pure Vanilla Extract" that impacted the inside flooring of trailer #3112792. The caller stated that the drum had been punctured by its own pallet. ERTS dispatched LSHR to conduct cleanup. At 2350 ET, LSHR personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 35 gallons released to a 5' x 5' area of the trailer and a 6' x 5' area of the concrete lot below the trailer. Absorbents were worked into the impacted areas and collected into a 55 gallon poly drum. The damaged drum was placed into a 95 gallon poly drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: At 1520 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at 402 South O'Brien, Wickett, TX. It was reported that an unknown amount of an unknown product was released into trailer #3171892 due to damage during transit. The caller stated the spill was on the nose of the trailer and was unable to determine the product or amount spilled. ERTS dispatched Lone Star Hazmat Response (LSHR) to conduct cleanup. At 1700 ET, LSHR personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5 gallons of product released to s 3' x 3' area of the trailer floor from two pails. A total of 5 pails were found to be damaged and were placed into (2) 95 gallon poly drums along with all impacted absorbents generated. The waste was transported to the XPO terminal located in Odessa, TX for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO terminal LEP reported a release of 2 liters of "Domes Resin - POL Part Type 03" (UN2290) from a 15-gallon metal drum. The release was caused by improper loading inside of the trailer. ERTS dispatched Talon LPE to conduct cleanup. Talon personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5 gallons of product released to a 6' x 2' area of the trailer floor due to a hairline crack in drum. Absorbents were placed down and crew contained the material under the pallet. Once the absorbents were worked in they were collected along with the damaged drum into a 55 gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: When loading the drum at customers site there were no signs of leakage. But upon arrival at the Veolia's 10 day intransit facility a small wet spot was identified under the drum. It was identified that the bottom (underneath side) of the drum had a few corroded spots. It is assumed that possibly one of the bottles packed in plastic inside the drum broke or became punctured during transport and the material leaked through the hole on the bottom of the drum. The drum was overpacked into a salvage container for continued transportation to the disposal site.

  • City: ABILENE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics reported that a pallet containing 36-5 gallon poly pails of UN3266 Zep Morado Super Cleaner fell over in transit causing approximately half a gallon to spill in the trailer from an unknown amount of pails. ERTS dispatched DSC Environmental to investigate and clean the release. At 0700 ET, DSC personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 6 gallons of product released to a 10' x 6' area of the trailer floor from 3 damaged containers. Absorbents were worked into the impacted area and then collected. The damaged pails and all cleanup debris were containerized into (2) 55 gallon poly drums which were staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: At 0735 ET, XPO reported a spill in Garland TX. XPO advised that due to improper loading a 5 gallon metal can of velocity paint thinner UN1263 was brushed and punctured by a pallet releasing two gallons onto the trailer floor. ERTS dispatched Allied International to conduct cleanup. At 1034 ET, AIE personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10 gallons of product released to s 2' x 2' area of the trailer floor from two damaged paint cans. Absorbents were worked into the impacted area and then collected. The spent absorbents, damaged pails, and all cleanup debris was containerized into a 55 gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: At 0949 ET, XPO terminal LSX reported a spill that occurred on the dock in San Antonio, TX. The spill consisted of a 29 gallon plastic drum of BIOBAN O 5P5 Antimicrobial, which was punctured by a forklift during dock operations and released approximately 1 gallon onto the floor. ERTS dispatched Milstead HMR to conduct cleanup. At 1205 ET, contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 gallon of product released to a 6' x 6' area of the dock floor. Absorbents were worked into the impacted area and then collected. The damaged drum and all cleanup debris were containerized into a 95 gallon poly drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-23
  • City: SPRING
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Union Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: UTLX 650419 was reported leaking from the top by yard personnel at the Lloyd Yard, Spring, Texas. Inspection found the Manway Inlet Gasket was not properly installed in the Manway Lid allowing material to release when car was moved. Gasket was deformed as a result and was removed. A new replacement Nozzle Gasket was installed and Manway Lid was closed, Swingbolts tightened tool tight, and car decontaminated. Tank car was returned to transportation.

  • Description: At approximately 1600 on 08-16-2022 the Pasadena Yardmaster recieved a call from an unknown worker at Ethyl Corp who observed a car going by the road crossing leaking product down the side of the car, the Yardmaster contacted the train crew and PTRA Trainmaster, train was stopped and inspection made, once car was located it was noted that product was evaporating before reaching the ground. At 17:00 PTRA contacted Slick Response stating that there was a leaking railcar spotted in route to a facility and asked that Slick Response respond to the car located at East Blvd. siding and make any needed repairs. At 18:15 Slick personnel arrived on location and secured the track with PTRA personnel then proceded to climb on top the car. Upon climbing on the car, the product was observed coming from inside of the containment dome. Upon opening the dome, the 3" ball valve was observed to be 1/4 turn open and the 3" plug was less than hand tight. After closing the valve, Slick personnel tightened the plug then checked the additional plugs and valvs where they were also found to be loose but not leaking. Slick then rinsed the car with water then secured the dome for transit. At 19:00 Slick personnel completed repairs to the car and have released the car back to PTRA personnel.

item.description:
Report E-2023010131

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-03
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 3, 2022, ERTS was contacted by Landstar personnel in Laredo, Texas requesting facilitation of the cleanup of a trailer impacted by spilled paint. ERTS then dispatched contractors to manage all onsite cleanup activities. Following contractor arrival and assessment of the involved cargo, it was determined that approximately three (3) gallons of W111 Waterbased Coating (Environmentally Hazardous Substance, Liquid, n.o.s., Marine Pollutant (Zinc Oxide), UN3082) spilled from a crack at the bottom of the involved container that was presumed to have been caused as the result of “stress” from overhead weight caused by a load shift. Contractors cleaned up the release using absorbents, hand tools and the proper PPE. The damaged pail, spent absorbents and all other waste generated were containerized in (1) 55-gallon plastic drum. The waste drum was then transported by the contractor to US Ecology disposal facility in Robstown, Texas for proper disposal.

  • Description: This shipment was found to be leaking during the sort. Upon inspection of the contents it was a FedEx Padded Pak and inside was one metal can (with positive closure) of paint. There was no absorbent or cushioning. The paint had leaked. Standard spill cleanup procedures were followed and the package was contained in a 1A2 steel drum pending final disposition. The manufacturer's safety data sheet listed this as UN 1263, Paint, class 3, Packing Group III. As the shipper did not offer this with any DG marks, labels, shipper's declaration. This is undeclared/hidden dangerous goods. The FAA was notified via their email process and photos and the SDS were sent.

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-22
  • City: MONAHANS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 22, 2022 at 0833 ET, Landstar contacted ERTS to request spill response for a reported UN1993 cargo release. Following contractor arrival and assessment of the involved cargo, it was determined that only a single tote was leaking from a “BB” sized puncture toward the bottom of the leaking tote. No other totes were observed to be leaking. Based on the location of the puncture, which was not able to be punctured or rubbed by adjacent cargo, the contractor could not determine the cause of the puncture. The tote contents were subsequently transferred into a “new” tote and absorbent was spread over the 20ft by 5ft area of concrete that was impacted. Once the crew completed operations it was determined that an estimated 95 gallons had been released to the concrete lot. The crew collected and containerized the absorbents into the damaged tote and departed the site with waste until proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2022090012
item.description:
Report E-2022090012

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-10
  • City: SOCORRO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 10, 2022 at 1335 ET, Landstar contacted ERTS regarding a UN1263, Paint, 3, PG II release that occurred inside of a trailer at Petro, 1295 Horizon Blvd., Socorro, TX. ERTS dispatched a contractor to perform the clean up and assess the impacted areas. Graymar arrived onsite and located the release, they confirmed only one gallon had released on to the trailer floor due to a puncture from a nail in a pallet. Graymar used absorbents on the affected areas of the trailer. One 55-gallon DM was generated containing the damaged pail and impacted absorbents. Waste is still pending disposal.

  • City: HOUSTON

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 25, 2022, four (4) 5-gallon pails of paint (UN1263) were crushed during transit and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from HazMat Special Services (HSS) to perform the necessary corrective actions. HSS personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surface, then containerized all paint-impacted material into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: THE BOX WAS DISCOVERED WHEN THE DOORS OF THE TRAILER WERE OPENED. THE BOX WAS ON ITS TOP, LEAKING. THE PH TRAINER CALLED THE MANAGER AND THE HAZMAT TEAM. THE LIQUID WAS NEUTRALIZED AND COVERED IN DUCK ABSORB. THE BOXES THAT WERE DAMAGED AS A RESULT WERE REMOVED AND THE WASTE BAGGED UP. DescribePack: ASIDE BEING LOADED ON ITS TOP, INSIDE THE BOX, ONE BOTTLE'S TOP WAS OFF AND ANOTHER'S WAS LOOSE. ALL FOUR BOTTLES WERE CRUSHED AND STAINED. THE BOX WAS SATURATED AND NO LONGER HAD A TOP. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: THE REMAINING BOTTLES WERE CLEANED AND BAGGED SEPARATELY. ALL DAMAGED MATERIALS WERE PLACED IN A LINED SALVAGE DRUM FOR FURTHER TRANSPORT.

item.title: Report X-2022081416
item.description:
Report X-2022081416

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-02
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: On 8-3-22, my supervisor informed me to check a damaged HazMat package that was in the QA HazMat cage. The package was coded a 39 on 8-2-22. The damaged package was inside a blue plastic HazMat bag that was inside a red HazMat container. Upon inspection, I found that the HazMat was inside a plastic container that had a lid that appeared secure. The lid was also taped, with plastic tape, to the container. However, upon tilting the plastic container, I found it to leak from underneath the lid, near the left handle. Approximately, 3 ounces had leaked from the plastic container onto the package bottom. No damage was observed on the plastic container or the outer package. The package had the upright arrows, but it had to be turned upside down at some point for it to leak. Pictures were taken and all required reports will be filled. DescribePack: The package was leaking from underneath the lid, near the left handle. The lid was also taped to the container with plastic tape, but it still leaked. No damage, holes, or cracks were observed on container. The container only leaked when tilted. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The HazMat package was placed inside a blue plastic Hazmat bag which was then placed inside a red plastic Hazmat container. The package was positioned in an upright position to avoid further spillage.

item.description:
Report E-2022080906

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-17
  • City: Richardson
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 17, 2022, one (1) 55-gallon drum of H.B. Fuller XR-5339-YRC was damaged during transit and released approximately fifty-five (55) gallons of product to the asphalt and trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from TAS Environmental Services (TASES) to perform the necessary corrective actions. TASES personnel utilized granular absorbents, power washing, hand tools, and drum vacuum operations to remediate the impacted surfaces. All impacted materials were containerized into five (5) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

  • Description: DMP RECEIVED A CALL TO THE UNLOAD FOR A LEAKING PACKAGE. WHEN THE RESPONDER ARRIVED FOUND THAT THE PACKAGE WAS A HAZMAT. THE LEAKING PACKAGE WAS CLEANED UP FOLLOWING ALL DMP PROCEDURES AND BROUGHT BACK TO THE DMP FOR PROCESSING. ONCE BACK IN DMP IT WAS FOUND THAT THE HAZMAT PACKAGE CONTAINED A CAR BATTERY THAT HAD LEAKED CAUSING THE WET SPOTS FROM THE INSIDE OUT. THE BATTERY WAS PROCESSED FOLLOWING ALL DMP PROCEDURES WITHOUT INCIDENT.

Upon inspection it was found that six manway swing bolts were found to be less than tool-tight, which led to the product release during movement. item.title: Report E-2022080113
item.description:
Report E-2022080113

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-01
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Monday 8/1/22, at approx. 6:30 P.M. CDT, Clean Harbors was contacted by Union Pacific Rail personnel to advise that we had a rail car that was leaking an unknown Hazardous Material. Union Pacific Rail personnel contacted United Professional Services (UPS) to respond and clean/remediate the rail tank car. UPS personnel determined that the material was being released from the manway of the rail car and was Raw Gas Oil. The cause of the release was a faulty gasket between the chime of the manway and the lid. UPS personnel replaced the gasket and secured the manway. UPS personnel advised that the manway was properly closed/torqued when they opened the manway to determine the cause of the release. They determined by use of a strapping chart that the total amount released was approx. 5 gal. The remediation efforts generated a 5 gallon bucket of soiled absorbent pads and microbial solution to clean the side of the rail car. This waste material will be manifested and shipped to a final disposal location by United Professional Services. No product was released to the ground.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Frontier Justice shipped a cardboard gaylord on a pallet with labels for Exxon Mobil oil. The BOL read only brass in the description. The gaylord actually contained spent and live ammunition with loose gunpowder. When offloading with a forklift, the gaylord exploded. It eventually lead to the death of the forklift driver two days later. A second gaylord was removed from the trailer and a 5 gallon bucket worth of powder was found.

item.title: Report I-2022100025
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-25
  • City: Texas City
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: TEXAS CITY TERMINAL RAILWAY CO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 07/25/2022- a Car Hire employee with TMC was doing car inspections when he noticed a smell from one of the cars (ACFX 71553) After looking closly he noticed that car had a small leak from the bottom valve of the railcar. He removed himself from the tank car and contacted the Yardmaster to report the leak. Once everyone was contacted from the hazardous incident repsonse plan. A reposentive from DOW Chemical was on site to inspect the tank car. They reported that the car was Ieaking from the gasket on the bottom valve of the railcar. They were able to correct the leak from the gasket. There was no puddle or residual chemical noticable on the track so TCT decied to let everything settle for 1 hour. The car was then taken back into OTTC. When the car was weighed there was not a weight difference from the weight on Friday and the weight we recorded today as it was going back to OTTC. Car Mark- ACFX 71553

  • Description: On July 20, 2022, Landstar called ERTS to for a spill of UN 1203 racing fuel from one of their trailers due to an accident that occurred on I-10 East in Fannette, TX. The caller advised the truck rolled over off of the road into the soil. ERTS dispatched OMI to perform the clean-up. Before the contractors arrived, the fire department was on site and called All Spills Environmental, TNT Wrecker was onsite, and said they would handle the spill. OMI confirmed a total of 24 were opened or leaking drums. OMI reports the truck was removed and no vehicle fluids were released. All waste was taken to TNT's yard in Beaumont until properly disposed of.

  • Description: XPO Terminal LFW contacted ERTS to make notification of an approximate 3 gallon spill of an unknown product. ERTS dispatched AIE to conduct cleanup. AIE personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5 gallons of UN 3266 Morado Super Cleaner released from a 5 gallon poly pail due to a forklift puncture. The release impacted a 4' x 15' and 5' x 8' area of the trailer floor. Absorbents were worked into the impacted areas and collected. The damaged pail and all cleanup debris were then collected and containerized into a 55 gallon poly drum which was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: CBTX 743234 was found leaking vapor in the Dayton, TX rail yard on 7/16/2022. BNSF Contractor was dispatched and found CBTX 743234 leaking from the manway due to the 2 of 6 manway swing bolts being less than tool tight. BNSF Contractor properly secured the manway swing bolts and CBTX 743234 was released to destination. CBTX 743234 was billed as UN1203, but the car was placarded as UN1268. A request was sent to L Energy International LLC to determine if the proper billing was submitted to the BNSF Railway.

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-13
  • City: HILLSBORO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 13, 2022, Landstar notified ERTS of a 5-10 gallon release of UN1760 Step Down “Stripping Solution” that impacted the trailer tire well, trailer floor and the concrete underneath the trailer. ERTS dispatched a remediation contractor to address the reported spill of UN1760. Grones Environmental arrived onsite, who following assessment of the involved cargo, determined that 5-gallons of product leaked from a single 5-gallon pail as the result of a crack at the bottom of the pail that was likely caused following a load shift. A Degreaser and oil dri were used appropriately to address the impacted areas. One 55-gallon poly drum was generated and staged at the contractors location until it is disposed of properly.

item.title: Report X-2022080823
item.description:
Report X-2022080823

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-19
  • City: SAN ANTONIO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF Freight
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Dock worker, Brandon Cutler, came into the Supervisors' office at about 1900, to notify Cherilyn Baker, of the hazmat spill. Cutler was going to unload the pallet of hazardous material, when his forklift blade punctured the bottom edge of the drum. Brandon was instructed to get the clean sweep, as B aker got the salvage drum. Baker instructed Cutler to lift the pallet up with the fork lift, so clean sweep could be poured under the pallet, to prevent it from escaping out of the trailer and onto the outside pavement. Cutler lowered the pallet and Alex Hostler came and helped Brandon tip the damag e drum on it's side, to prevent from leaking any further. Hostler and Cutler placed the damage drum on a pallet that they lined with cardboard, to prevent from leaking further onto the dock.

item.title: Report X-2022080599
item.description:
Report X-2022080599

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-19
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: This is an email from the manager that located the item. He is former QA and has held/has certification. There was a Hazmat that spilled on the Silver Belt by Door 603 during the Sunrise sort. It was determined that the Hazmat in question was a Toxic Flammable Liquid known as Pyridine, confirmed via the OP-950 on the package and strong fish like odor associated with the chemical. I called the emergency contact number and got a hold of Ron with Chemtec on proper clean-up process. The process that he instructed us to do was to put some form of absorbent on the spill and keep the area well ventilated, which Noelia and I did immediately following the spill. We removed the trailers from the dock in order to better ventilate the area. Once the spill has been completely absorbed, we are to use rubber gloves and eye protection to scoop up the absorbent and we are to use a plastic shovel to avoid any possibilities of creating sparks. It was advised an Emergency Response Team was not necessary for the situation given we followed the proper procedures immediately following the spill. Report number given to me by the Chemtec Rep was #2022070200060 which he gave to me in order to prove validation that we successfully reported the spill. DescribePack: This chemical is very strong smelling and it was difficult even with PPE to thoroughly inspect each area. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: There was a Hazmat that spilled on the Silver Belt by Door 603 during the Sunrise sort. It was determined that the Hazmat in question was a Toxic Flammable Liquid known as Pyridine, confirmed via the OP-950 on the package and strong fish like odor associated with the chemical. I called the emergency contact number and got a hold of Ron with Chemtec on proper clean-up process. The process that he instructed us to do was to put some form of absorbent on the spill and keep the area well ventilated, which Noelia and I did immediately following the spill. We removed the trailers from the dock in order to better ventilate the area. Once the spill has been completely absorbed, we are to use rubber gloves and eye protection to scoop up the absorbent and we are to use a plastic shovel to avoid any possibilities of creating sparks. It was advised an Emergency Response Team was not necessary for the situation given we followed the proper procedures immediately following the spill. Report number given to me by the Chemtec Rep was #2022070200060 which he gave to me in order to prove validation that we successfully reported the spill.

item.description:
Report E-2022080316

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-07
  • City: SAN ANTONIO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistic terminal LSX reported 2-gallons of UN1993 "IPAC 9893L" release impacting the trailer floor and asphalt below due to a knock out cap missing from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched Lone Star Hazmat Response for all onsite clean up operations. At 1440 ET, Lone Star arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released affecting a 2’ x 2’ area of the trailer floor/asphalt below. Contractors transferred all salvageable product into a new tote and collected and containerized the damaged cut-up tote and all clean-up debris into (1) 55-gallons metal drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from Ambipar Response (AR) to perform the necessary corrective actions. AR personnel drummed the damaged containers, then utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surfaces.

item.title: Report E-2022080123
item.description:
Report E-2022080123

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-07
  • City: EL PASO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 1236 ET, XPO terminal LEP reported a spill that occurred in El Paso, TX. The spill consisted of boxes containing UN1090 Satwipes which were crushed due to too much freight stacked on top of them, causing an unknown amount of flammable liquid to spill onto the tail of the trailer. Some fumes were reported to be emitting from the boxes as well. ERTS dispatched GrayMar to conduct cleanup. At 1530 ET, contractors arrived onsite and observed a damaged poly bag of wipes. The product did not appear to release to the trailer floor and spill was contained to the package only. The damaged bag was placed into a 15 gallon metal waste drum and the remaining freight on the pallet was stacked for continued transit. Waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2022080100
item.description:
Report E-2022080100

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-13
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: MESA AIR GROUP, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Captain Statement: While taxiing onto the runway to line up and wait, the flight attendant called and advised a first row passenger had a cell phone that began to smoke and that she had placed it into the Thermal Containment Bag. We advised ATC, cleared the runway to make contact with SOC and coordinate a return to gate. Maintenance met the plane and the TCB with the cell phone was removed from the plane. While waiting for a replacement TCB, I worked with UA gate staff to make sure the passenger understood the process. Upon completion of the maintenance procedures we departed without any further incident. Flight Attendant 1 Statement: We were on the runway in line for take off, I was in my jump seat and noticed smoke coming out of a cell phone. Pax was in 1C. Her child had been playing with the phone. the Mom and i noticed the smoke at the same time. I jumped out of my seat grabbed the phone, threw it in the galley, Called the Capitan, and checked for heat on the the phone. I happed so fast I am not sure the order in which this happened. Once I was satisfied that the phone was not hot, I placed the phone and the charger in the red Thermal bag and zipped it. The PAX was upset and insisted that it was the outlet and not the phone, I felt the out let it was cool. I personally saw smoke coming out of the bottom of the phone. We went back to the gate and the CA handled the situation from there. the lady wanted her phone back but the CA would not allow it back on the plane (thank Goodness). Flight Attendant 2 Statement: Pilot was literally about to take off when FA1 Janey saw smoke in the air. She immediately called Pilot to inform him to not take off then proceeded to get out of jumpseat and assist 1C. She was not sure if it was the charger, phone, or outlet so she put the items in the TCB. Once we went back to the gate, Mesa MTC came on board as well as gate agents. finally, we were told to leave the items behind while the passenger insisted that she wanted her phone back.

  • Description: July 15th 2022 at 0700 ET, XPO Logistics terminal LHW called to report a 16 ounce release of UN3267 Wheel Strip 273-WL Industrial Liquid Paint Stripper due to a possible forklift puncture. The terminal came across the release on the trailer while trying to unload. ERTS dispatched Milstead HMR to conduct cleanup. At 0850 ET, contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 6 ounces of product released to a 1' x 1' area of the trailer floor. The damaged drum and all cleanup debris was containerized into a 95 gallon poly drum which was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2022070925
item.description:
Report E-2022070925

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-05
  • City: ODESSA
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 05, 2022, Landstar contacted ERTS requesting to dispatch a remediation contractor to address a reported “unknown amount of UN2924 released from a 275-gallon IBY tote after being punctured. Following contractor arrival and visual assessment, it was concluded based on this assessment and discussion with a ChampionX representative on site that the driver left the ChampionX facility and at some point, had to apply his brakes very abruptly causing the load to shift forward. The strap holding the tote appeared to have bent the cage surrounding the tote which then punctured the plastic part of the tote causing the release. Driver then turned around and went back to the ChampionX facility where the product leaked onto their parking lot. A 25' by 15' area of the concrete was impacted and a 6' by 6' area of dirt was impacted. The totes were offloaded and the trailer was wiped down with chemical pads. Allied transferred approximately 210 gallons of product into a new 230 gallon poly tote which ChampionX has deemed as waste. The tote will be staged onsite until Allied can return to pick up the tote for disposal. Absorbents were worked in and recovered and the impacted dirt was collected. Allied generated (3) 85-gallon poly overpacks, two of which contain product impacted absorbent, one containing impacted dirt and respirator cartridges. Waste is currently pending disposal.

item.description:
Report X-2022071006

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-18
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: THE PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED BY DESIGNATED RESPONDER. IT WAS FOUND TO BE A PREVIOUSLY LEAKING HAZMAT THAT HAD NOW DRIED AND WAS LEFT AS A SLIGHTLY DAMP PACKAGE WITH THE CONTENTS STILL INSIDE. THAT THE RESPONDER DONNED FULL PPE PRIOR TO TESTING THE CORROSIVE PH. THE LITTLE AMOUNT OF SPILLED HAZMAT WAS PH BALANCED AND SOLIDIFIED. THE CONTAINER WITH THE LOOSE CAP WAS RESCURED AND THE ENTIRE HAZMAT WAS COLLECTED TO BE PROCESSED IN THE DMP AREA.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Received a call that the car vented product 8-10 feet in the air for 8-10 seconds and then reseated. The car was inspected by contractors and found to have 150 psi and 21.5" outage with no release. Car was inspected about 2 hours later and had 270 psi. The car was reduced to 34" of outage on 7/23/22.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SHQX 6076 was reported by citizens to leaking from the top of the car. Inspection by response personnel found 4 of 4 mounting studs on the liquid valve to pressure plate to be less than tool tight. Nuts were tightened stopping the release. Car was decontaminated and moved to the Pierce yard nearby to be set out of train and held for repair and/or OTMA at time of report.

item.title: Report X-2022071000
item.description:
Report X-2022071000

  • City: LONGVIEW
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Received report of odor and audible hiss from the top of the car. Code 3, contractor, assessed the car and determined the car was releasing vapor from the PRD. The pressure was 250 psi,(PRD set at 280.5) and 25" of outage. The O-rings were assessed, the larger one appeared deteriorated. Both were changed and the release stopped. Car was placed in HZ hold awaiting an OTMA-1

  • Description: On July 21, 2022, at 2249 ET, Roadrunner reported 10- Pounds of UN1823 "Caustic Soda Micro Pearls" released to the inside of the trailer from a 50-pound paper bag due to improper loading. The terminal is requesting a contractor to come out to dispose of the waste.

item.title: Report X-2022070688

  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: RESPONDER WAS CALLED TO A LEAKING HAZMAT ON METRO 10, SPOT 1018. HAZMAT WAS FOUND ON THE GROUND, NEXT TO THE METRO LINE, IN A PUDDLE OF LIQUID AROUND 2 FEET BY 3 FEET IN SIZE. THE BOTTOM OF PART "A" PACKAGE WAS THROUGHLY SOAKED AND PART "B" WAS SITTING A FEW FEET AWAY WITH NO ISSUES TO NOTE. NO SPILLAGE WAS FOUND ON THE METRO BELT OR IN ANY PREVIOUS BELT/CHUTE THAT IT TRAVELED ON TO ARRIVE AT ITS LOAD LOCATION. CYLINDER WAS REMOVED FROM PACKAGE AND FOUND TO HAVE A OPEN/LEAKING VALVE AND SEVERLY DENT/CRIMPED BOTTOM HANDLE. THE RESIDUAL LIQUID WAS SOLIDIFIED, CYLINDER VALVE WAS CLOSED AND CLEANED OFF.

  • Description: On July 5, 2022, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing RoQuest 4000 was punctured during transit and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the trailer interior. Product further migrated to the asphalt roadway. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from Environmental Restoration, LLC (ER) to perform the necessary corrective action. ER personnel overpacked the damaged drum, then neutralized and absorbed free product utilizing solution and granular absorbents.

  • Description: Passenger Yost was traveling on SkyWest flight 3107, DFW-FAR. After she used her phone(i phone 12) to board the aircraft the Phone started heating up and would not turn off. Passenger Yost called the Flight Attendant for help. The flight attendant place the phone into the fire containment bag and added water to cool the device. ARFF was called and the aircraft returned to the gate. The phone and bag was removed by ARFF. There was not fire or smoke, this was a dangerous evolution of heat.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-22
  • City: Fort Worth
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: ON JUNE 22, 2022 AT APPROXIMATELY 1245, OUR STATION IN FT. WORTH TX RECEIVED THE PACKAGE CONTAINING A USED FUEL PUMP BEING RETURNED FOR MAINTENANCE. THE PUMP WAS CONTAMINATED WITH JET FUEL AND WAS PUT IN A PLASTIC BAG WITH ABSORBENT MATERIAL, WHICH WAS THEN PUT IN THE FIBERBOARD BOX. THE BAG WAS NOT SEALED PROPERLY AND SOME OF THE FUEL LEAKED OUT AND WAS ABSORBED BY THE FIBERBOARD BOX. THE BOX WAS NOT MARKED OR LABELED CORRECTLY. THE PACKAGE IS BEING HELD AT THE STATION FOR FURTHER DISPOSITION.

  • Description: At DFW Airport as customers were deplaning American Airlines Flight 2558 from Fort Lauderdale a customer's carry-on bag began to smoke. Customer was exiting aircraft and had just entered several steps onto jetbridge when incident occurred. Customer dumped contents of bag or purse onto jetbridge and ran off. Contents was an open tray charger containing 18650 lithium ion cells for an e-cigarette, dental floss, Q-tips and either a tube of hand Iotion or a small aerosol can of something.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The Petro Chemical Transport, LLC driver was delivering diesel fuel into the customer's storage tank. It appears that the storage tank may have overpressurized causing the flapper valve on the tank to shut. The driver tried to relieve the pressure by loosening the connection of the delivery hose with the tank trailer. When the driver attempted this, approximately 15 gallons of diesel fuel was released from the hose. Enviroserve responded and handled the remediation.

item.title: Report E-2022070479
item.description:
Report E-2022070479

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-27
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SAFETY-KLEEN SYSTEMS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The Sales and Service Representative picking up the drum from the generator failed to conduct a thorough container inspection which would have revealed a visibly corroded area on the drum body approx. 3" from the top rim of the drum. The Sales and Service Representative used an electric drill with a socket attachment to tighten the jam nut on the closure ring. The excessive torque delivered by the electric drill caused the jam nut to squeeze the closure ring too tight and the drum body split due to the weakened integrity of the side wall caused by the corrosion resulting in approx. 19 Gal. of the material to be released to the customer's concrete dock area.

item.title: Report E-2022070477
item.description:
Report E-2022070477

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-13
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ON June 13, 2022, Landstar notified ERTS of a UN2924 release in a Landstar Trailer# 698409 due to a forklift puncture. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. Upon contractor arrival, this puncture related spill incident was confirmed and the release, estimated at 55-gallons, affected trailer flooring components and an underlying area comprised of concrete. Accordingly, the responding contractor overpacked the damaged drum and then addressed affected trailer flooring and concrete surfaces utilizing absorbents and appropriate cleaning agents. E3 Environmental generated (3) 55-gallon drums, one containing 40 gallons of liquid product and the other 2 drums containing the impacted absorbents. The contractor used a supersack for the contaminated pallets and one 85-gallon drum was overpacked with the damaged drum. The contractor departed with the waste to profile and dispose of properly.

item.title: Report E-2022070475
item.description:
Report E-2022070475

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-13
  • City: ENNIS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 13, 2022, Landstar notified ERTS of a 30 gallon release of Grazon P+D due to the trailer being broken into during the night. The release impacted the inside of trailer #671931 and the asphalt parking lot. No storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release. Following contractor arrival and visual assessment, it was determined that a single 30-gallon drum spilled 30-gallons of product from a puncture at the bottom of the drum that occurred when a load shift occurred, which caused the drum to shift and subsequently be punctured by what was presumed to be a pallet nail. Media affected was limited to trailer flooring components and an underlying area of concrete. One 55-gallon poly drum contained the impacted absorbents and one 55-gallon drum contained the damaged drum. All waste was taken off site for profiling and then disposal.

DescribePack: The lid of the pail was slightly bent. The pail was completely empty. No spillage was seen around the pail. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Pail was completely empty when found. No leakage present.

item.title: Report E-2022070011
item.description:
Report E-2022070011

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-28
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 28, 2022, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing chloroform was punctured by a forklift and released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the trailer interior and concrete loading dock. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from HazMat Special Services (HMSS) to perform the necessary corrective action. HMSS personnel overpacked the damaged drum and utilized absorbents to remediate the impacted surfaces.

item.title: Report E-2022070000
item.description:
Report E-2022070000

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-30
  • City: Houston
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Thursday, June 30 at approximately 1400 hours PTRA switch crews reported a noxious odor in the Manchester yard. Slick Response was notified and responded with PTRA officers to the yard and were unable to find any indications of a release at 1500 hours. Several hours later at 1955 hours crews again reported an odor. Slick Response returned to the yard with PTRA managers and after walking several tracks responders found TILX 101045 releasing vapors from the PRD at approximately 2109 hours. The car, loaded sulfuric acid, spent, UN1832, was shipped from the Deer Park Refining LP (PEMEX) facility in Deer Park, TX. Plant personnel were notified of the vapor release from the PRD and they suggested we get the car to destination, Eco Services, approximately 2/10 of a mile from the site of the incident or we get water flowing through the coils of the car to cool the product. They also dispatched their own ER crew from SRS. PEMEX personnel suggested that the product may have a contaminant that was causing an exothermic reaction and building pressure in the tank. PTRA contacted the consignee, Eco Services, to see if they would accept the car in the current condition. They initially indicated that they would accept the car so arrangements were made to deliver the car to their facility. PTRA crews and managers moved the car to the north end of the yard across the street from Eco and requested that the gates be opened for delivery of the car. At that time the plant manager indicated that they would not be able to accept the car. Upon that notification the PTRA moved the car to a stub track adjacent to a water line where Slick Response and SRS Environmental personnel were able to connect the water line to the inlet for the coils. At that time the decision was made to shut down the yard and have all crews shelter in place at the main office building to the north of the yard until the car could be stabilized. Responders began flowing water through the coils at 0045 hours, they also vented some pressure to atmosphere to drop the pressure in the car. At that time a gauge was applied and showed an initial reading of 50 psi but it steadily began rising to 65 psi within a few minutes. With no way to control the rising pressure the decision was made to move the car approximately 7 miles to PEMEX, Deer Park Refining (the shipper) for offloading. Notifications were made to the NRC and voicemails left with FRA hazmat notifying them of the decision to move the car to PEMEX Deer Park. PTRA crews and mangers were briefed on the move, the car was secured, water lines removed and all lines closed and plugged for movement. A special train move was made to PEMEX Deer Park at 0415, the car was handed off to PEMEX Deer Park at 0510 hours. The shelter in place at PTRA Manchester yard was lifted at 0415. No injuries were reported.

item.title: Report E-2022060885
item.description:
Report E-2022060885

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-01
  • City: MARTINDALE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AUSTIN POWDER COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Austin Powder company driver Scott Cook was driving a 2007 Freightliner tractor, and pulling a non-specification pneumatic tanker in rural Caldwell county Texas around 6:00 PM on 6/1/22. The driver had just loaded up at the company's Seguin, TX location, and was making the trip back to his home terminal in Georgetown, TX. The driver had not yet scaled the load, but we estimate that it was around 46-47,000 of ammonium nitrate as cargo. The driver was familiar with the road and intersection. He was driving a truck that he was familiar with. The trailer was a different one than he usually used, this one being slightly heavier. The driver was negotiating a left hand turn on route 1979 (intersection with 621). Based on telematics data the rig was taking the turn around 20 MPH. Partway into the turn, the vehicle started to tip over. The driver tried to right the rig, but it overturned onto its passenger side, somewhat perpendicular to the road it had just turned onto, with part of it on the pavement and part on the grass. The latches on one of the dome lids opened due to the impact, and roughly 2 pounds of ammonium nitrate fell out onto the grass. The weather was clear and dry, and the area was free of water, so the product was contained in the roughly 2X3 area onto which it spilled. The driver was unhurt. He got out of the vehicle and began his emergency response procedures, which include contacting 911, Chemtrec, and company officials. First responders showed up directly afterwards, along with Austin Powder Company officials. Both roads in the intersection were closed at this point. A spill contractor was dispatched out to the scene in anticipation of more product leaking from the package. Wreckers were dispatched, and after a period of several hours, the truck and trailer were put upright. There was nothing for the spill contractor to clean up, and the roads were opened completely after a period of roughly 5 hours. The small amount of product (2 pounds) was given to the Austin Powder Company officials to take back to their facility.

  • State: TX

  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 23, 2022, one (1) 2,204-lbs super-sack containing sodium persulfate was torn by a forklift and released approximately three (3) pounds to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from Allied International Emergency (AIE) to perform the necessary corrective action. AIE personnel drummed all free product, patched the damaged container, then transferred virgin material into a new super-sack for continued use by RLC.

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-21
  • City: LONGVIEW
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Report of vapor release and hiss from the top of the car. Upon investigation it was determined that approximately 2/3 of the large o-ring in the REGO PRD was cut and protruding from under the O-ring retainer cap allowing vapor to release. An O-ring was installed and the leak stopped. Due to high heat and the concern of another release, an emergency verbal OTMA was received from the FRA to move the car to destination.

item.title: Report E-2022060790
item.description:
Report E-2022060790

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-07
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1142 ET, XPO Logistics (LLA) contacted ERTS to report a regulated cargo release. It was reported a 55 gallon metal drum containing XIAMETER PMX-1184 Silicone Fluid was discovered leaking due to improper loading, releasing a total of 1 gallon of the product to the trailer floor. ERTS dispatched E3 Environmental to conduct cleanup. AT 1322 ET E3 arrived onsite and advised approximately 8 gallons released to 5' x 10' area of the trailer due to a nick at the bottom of the drum. The damaged drum was placed into an 85 gallon metal drum. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area and then collected into a 55 gallon metal drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-03
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO terminal LDA reported a release of Bestolife Copper Based Production Compound due to an overturned metal tote. ERTS dispatched Lone Star Hazmat to conduct cleanup. At 0025 ET, contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100 gallons of product released to a 40' x 50' area of the dock floor due to damage to the tote valve. The valve was shrink wrapped and secured to prevent further release. The material was collected from the impacted area and containerized into (6) 55 gallon poly drums. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-15
  • City: CORPUS CHRISTI
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PICKED UP A HAZMAT PACKAGE FROM THE PACKAGE CAR LOADING DOCK. WHILE CARRYING THE PACKAGE INTO THE PACKAGE CAR, HE FELT A WET/HEAT SENSATION. AS HE PLACED THE PACKAGE ON THE PACKAGE CAR FLOOR , HE NOTICED LIQUID LEAKING FROM THE BOX. NOTIFIED DRIVER SUPERVISOR. RESPONDED TO THE SPILL, WHICH TURNED OUT TO BE A CORROSIVE LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE. I USED THE DECISION TREE AND DRESSED IN THE REQUIRED PPE, I CLEANED UP THE SPILLED MATERIAL AND TRANSPORTED THE PACKAGE TO THE DMP AREA FOR PROCESSING.

item.title: Report E-2022060416
item.description:
Report E-2022060416

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-01
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 0735 ET, XPO Logistics terminal, LDA notified ERTS of a release of UN1805 Phosphoric Acid from a 275 gallon tote due to a forklift puncture, impacting the dock. Oil Dri was put down as a barrier. ERTS dispatched Lone Star Hazmat to conduct cleanup. At 0933 ET, Lone Star personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 125 gallons of product released to a 75' x 50' area of the concrete dock floor and a 30' x 30' area of the asphalt lot below. Soda ash and absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to collect and neutralize the material. The remaining product in the damaged tote was pumped into a new tote. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all waste into (9) 55 gallon poly drums. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
